date_and_job: Sep 22, 2018 - Junior Financial Auditor in Brussels
pros:
A lot of responsibilities gives
Able to learn on a daily basis
Meet interesting people
Dynamic company

cons:
- Lack of flexibility (As a junior auditor, I couldn't arrive early and leave early in order to avoid traffic jam even if I was working in the headquarters for instance)
- High pressure during the busy season, between January and April and so poor work-life balance
- Time estimation for the audit missions is rarely accurate especially during the busy season and thus you will have to work much more for some clients
- Bad allocation of audit missions, I sometimes had to drive more than 90 kms going through the whole ring of Brussels during the busy season
- Not much appreciation given regarding the work done
pros:
- Lots of young people  
- International environment
- Opportunities to network
- Good training

cons:
C
(Disclaimer: big company, so might not be representative)
-Politics, politics, politics
-Very hierarchical, job levels are very important, partner says jump, you say how high, watch out what you say
-High pressure and quite stressful, I've seen colleagues cry, negative atmosphere in general,  people complaining all the time, everything is always so serious, problematic and urgent
-open office/flex desk: nice trend but not easy to concentrate 
-Competitive 
-a job that takes over your life, you're always on call
-“interesting” e-mail culture: everything happens in writing only vs personal communication 
-you don’t get the feeling that you matter; you’re just a number 
-practical problems, simply getting to the office  is often a challenge (parking!)
-very Flemish (depends on your assignment of course), you might feel that you don't fit in if you're not
-you're supposed to take most of your vacation during (summer) school holidays and between Christmas and new year office is closed but it gets deducted from your vacation days.

I’m having a great learning experience but working in such a big Belgian(Flemish) company really isn’t for everyone.
pros:
-looks good on CV
-Smart, dedicated colleagues, most are very friendly
-Nice perks (fancy office, nice cars even for all juniors...)
-High-end company events
-some training/info sessions 
-Kind management 
-Big budgets

If you are ok with work taking over your life, if you're skilled at navigating through political games, if you are fine with being part of a "tribe", if you’re Belgian, go for it! You'll have great possibilities and interesting experiences and the name on your curriculum.

cons:
- Work life balance is very, very bad
- Constant pressure on your shoulders
- Promotion is not based on the quality of your work
date_and_job: Jun 14, 2018 - IT Business Analyst in Brussels
post_title: Speak loud before you do actually something
pros:
- Dynamic colleagues
- Interesting projects

cons: Politics inside the company difficult the progress. Standardisation for a single Deloitte.
pros: Great methodology betting on sales critical aspects of a project delivery

cons: - junior people handling senior projects
pros: + the diversity, career prospects and internal training offer

cons:
- Work 70-80 hours a week and receive no recognition or gratitude in return
- Expect to give up social life, sometimes weekends and all your hobbies for work
- They sell your total "package" of remunerations as market competitive, but you receive very low pay considering the hours you are expected to work
- Absolutely horrible atmosphere at the HQ. Feels like a grave yard where people are afraid of engaging in conversations (or maybe it's just a Belgian thing)
- Leadership only cares about staffing consultants to hit their targets. They squeeze and bleed BAs/Cs/SCs as much as they possible can
- Office politics decide whether you get promoted, receive bonus, etc. Licking the rights boots will get you far.
- Senior managers are all overworked and look miserable 24/7
pros:
- Brand name
- Good learning curve
- Nice colleagues (those at same level)
- Variety of trainings

cons: forget your life, your friends and your family, this is only corporate life.
pros: Learning and developing skills, challenging environment, networking.

cons:
It will be almost 1 year in Deloitte Digital - Belgium. Before joining Deloitte-Belgium, 7years i was working as  developer/Team lead for a specific technology. During the several rounds of interview, Deloitte told me there are innovation development going on and bla bla bla.. But after joining i realized there is NO project on that technology which i have learned and experienced for last 7 years. And they sold me to a client by telling that I’m an expert of another technology which client was demanding . Management pressurized  me to learn that new technology within few weeks. There was no training & guidance what so ever.  Like this they asked me to work on 6 different technologies in 9 months. Then i realized its the time to save my career rather than to stay for the shake of the brand "DELOITTE”. 
I have seen people leaving because they were hired for digital marketing and asked to work as project manager.  So if you really want to spoil your career then it might be one of the best place.
post_title: worst company - your career may spoil here
pros: Cant think of anything except few good people.

cons:
- work life balance can be difficult, especially when you have children since many team meetings etc happen after working hours to not interfere with the client work
- no attention is paid to home location vs. client location, e.g. you might be required to travel to a client for a year that means 3-5hour commute a day
- high expectations and workload, you are expected to take on many responsibilities next to the client work, even if you are working on clients 100% or more of your time
- salary is below market because you get many opportunities to learn and grow, but as of a certain level, you are assumed to teach and help grow the junior/senior consultants, even though salary remains under the market
pros:
- learning opportunities, trainings internal and external, certifications
- flexibility to work on several projects, different departments, different companies and sectors

cons: salary below market but good benefits
pros: Good ambiance, international company, progressive career, possibility to have an impact on the files

cons: .. these are all cosy prisons, I ended up working 55-60 h a week and had enough.

pros: Having worked for Deloitte for one year now, the company supports its employees with lots of trainings and follow-up. The work content is extremely varied, and on most projects very interesting and learningful. High speed learning curve guaranteed.

post_title: A good company to work for despite a lot of sacrifices on private field
pros:
- You get a lot of experience very quickly
- You can work on lot of projects
- Work ambiance is pretty good

cons: I worked in the Belgian office (Diegem) which was a sweatshop as it didn't allow for too much work balance for people below Manager level. It's useful to have a couple of years at Deloitte on your CV but takes great strength of character or very clear reasons for staying longer (e.g. networking). Try to negotiate your level when entering the company as high as possible since subsequent promotion doesn't bring significant additional compensation, financially speaking.
pros: Excellent diversity of projects, but that pretty much depends on the Partner you're working for. Working for international projects and meeting all kinds of experts was the great part of being there.

cons:
Low pay below partner level
